text:
Hi Alex. Sorry to reply only now, I was a bit busy. 

Letâ€™s see how I can help you. 

What is it that you enjoy most so far, or what is it that you feel most confident with? What do you want to do in the future? 

What is the cursus at your University?

I'm really taking to zbrush I love using zbrush, I also seem to have taken to Compositing a bit even though nuke is very hard to learn and use lol, atm I think im heading towards the modelling/creature route as I'm more confident in that are.

In the future I think i could be either a modeller/sculpter or a compositor but I would be happy going any route as I'm willing to learn anything.

My course is visual effects.

What will you get at the end of the course? A short film, a reel? When do you finish?

From my experience, being a generalist is a good thing, as studios can make better use of your skills and keep you busy. So I would say, learn texturing as well.

Compositing is a very different task. I come from there. It doesn't really have direct links with modelling/texturing though. It is more complementary to lighting, I would say.
Is there anything specific I can help you with? What are you expecting from this interaction?

My course finishes next year, next May and hopefully I'll have a decent showreel then, we focus a lot on the visual effects so I'll probably have a combination of things I could add or multiple reels showing skills like Compositing, modelling, texturing.

I have been doing a little bit of texturing I've just started learning substance painter to texture my assets.

In terms of Compositing I don't mind roto scoping I know roto scoping is an entry job so I think it's a good skill to have.

What I'm hoping to get out of this the most is to learn from your experience in the industry like maybe internships I should apply for (I'm thinking of applying for framestores internship) or should I just focus on my course, showreel advice like length and content, maybe get your advice on some of my work and how I can get the best chance of standing out and getting a job when I finish uni, cv advice, I haven't got one yet but I'm thinking of personalising it to fit my personality like if I was applying for framestore I would go for like an avengers style, very bright maybe some images to stand out more.

Ok. Then we'll figure that out once you get images or videos you feel are worth being in your reel.

Things have changed a lot since I started and I now see most people starting with an internship or being runners. I'll ask around what the best approach is. That said, given that you are currently studying, I would make the most of it. Entry-level jobs can much less exciting than the freedom you'll have while studying.

That's what I was thinking I plan to finish and enjoy my time at uni. I'll probably have some things to show when I finish this term in May, confetti where I'm studying are great at actually getting people who are in the industry to come in and talk to us so I've met a lot of people working in the industry from people from framestore to DNEG, I also already have a LinkedIn which I've added you or ready as a connection and people I've met.

Were actually going on a trip to London next week and will be visiting some studious such as ilm and framestore so that will great to see and meet people and were also going to the vfx festival.

I'm wondering as well whether it's best to try for smaller studios as well cause they may be looking for people just coming out of uni with little experience compared to much bigger studios where its much harder to get noticed. A lot of people have told me it's all about who you know which is why I applied for this and got a LinkedIn to build connections and that.

Also anything visual effects fancisinates me so I'm happy to take it anywhere from games to TV to advertising. I just want to be able to get my foot through the door when I finish uni, I've heard you need to want it which I know i do.

I'll be off from the 16th until the end of March or mid-April, TBC.

I prefer smaller studios as I feel they are more human than bigger ones. That said, bigger studios often get bigger shows, which can be exciting, especially when you are starting in the industry. I quite like Cinesite, where I have been for more than three years now. A good size. Not too small so we get exciting work, not too big so one still gets to know everybody.

Advertising, TV, film, are quite different in terms of pace. I don't really know the games industry, although I know some artists who go from games to vfx quite often.

I think smaller studios could be the way to go especially for me trying to get noticed, I mean i want to work on exciting projects but also get to know people and have a nice working environment it just depends where I end up. I plan to apply for as many places as possible as one will hopefully have me then as I get more experience I'll probably find what I really want to do whether it is films, games, advertising or TV, the first hurdle is just getting my foot through the door and building a good showreel which I hope you'll help me with cause if you approve of my showreel I think they will stand me in good stead.
Do you have a reference image?
I modelled it in maya

Good. Not quite matching the reference though, which is something you would get asked to do in production. 

Should you want to work in vfx, I would develop a photo-real reel rather than one replicating game assets :)
Yeah cheers, I've just heard the vfx festival has been cancelled cause of the coronavirus, seems like it's been affecting quite a bit of business to
All companies are working on contingency plans.
Not suprised especially in the film industry if more films start getting delayed like no time to die or box office results start falling cause people arnt going to cinema.
Btw do you think it's harder now for people just coming out of uni to get a job in vfx, I have heard though that there has been an outcry for more vfx artists

The industry desperately needs more artists as with the streaming services, there is more demand than ever for high quality visual effects. Also Brexit is going to drastically reduce the number of European artists coming to the UK. In the VFX industry, 40% of artists are not from the UK.
On the other hand, there are also now quite a few schools teaching visual effects, so the level of artists joining the industry has raised significantly, meaning there is quite a bit of competition.

That is interesting do you think that will open more opportunities to people like me once brexit happens and the competition is why I want to make sure I've got the best chance I can of getting a foothold in the industry, one of the reasons I applied for this.

I hate to say it, but I think Brexit is going to give British students starting in the industry more chances as the visa cost, nhs upfront payment and minimum wage threshold, make it much less interesting and difficult for foreigners to come for work in the UK. 

On the other side, I donâ€™t think the UK can train enough vfx artists in the time we have, to compensate for the sudden loss of European artists.

I would always be up for working abroad, I know working in vfx you potentially get the opportunity to travel to many different places maybe not at first but eventually

As a vfx supervisor it must be great being able to travel and go on set and that, can I ask what projects you've been involved in at cinesite.
The latest one was Bond, which was postponed by 7 month after madly trying to deliver it in time.

Yeah that must be frustrating, I was really looking forward to bond. I'm a big film lover I go to the cinema all the time part of the reason why I wanted to work in vfx as when I see a film I always go, I wish i could have worked on that. Any other big projects?
The previous one was a completely different beast: a stunt show for Universal Studios Orlando based on the Jason Bourne franchise. It is about to open. It was 19â€™ long, full CG, 9k wide, 60 FPS.
Logging off for today. Have a good evening.
Cheers, thanks for all the advice today.
